description: Number of segments needed to represent n on calculator display.
comments: a(A216261(n)) = n and a(m) <> n for m < A216261(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 15 2013
references: Netnews group rec.puzzles, Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) file. (Science Section).
Clifford A. Pickover, A Passion for Mathematics, Wiley, 2005; see p. 65.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Nathaniel Johnston, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
formula: a(n) = a(floor(n/10) + a(n mod 10) for n > 9. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 15 2013
maple: A006942 := proc(n) local d,dig,j,s: if(n=0)then return 6:fi: dig:=[6,2,5,5,4,5,6,3,7,6]: d:=convert(n,base,10): s:=0: for j from 1 to nops(d) do s:=s+dig[d[j]+1]: od: return s: end: seq(A006942(n),n=0..100); # Nathaniel Johnston, May 08 2011
mathematica: MapIndexed[ (f[First[#2] - 1] = #1)& , {6, 2, 5, 5, 4, 5, 6, 3, 7, 6}]; a[n_] := Plus @@ f /@ IntegerDigits[n]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 76}] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Sep 25 2012 *)
prog: (Haskell)a006942 n = a006942_list !! na006942_list = [6,2,5,5,4,5,6,3,7,6] ++ f 10 where   f x = (a006942 x' + a006942 d) : f (x + 1)         where (x',d) = divMod x 10-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 15 2013
crossrefs: For other versions of this sequence see A010371 A018846 A018847 A018849 A038136 A053701 A063720.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
